Award.AwardTitle: III: Small: BigSolver: Data-Intensive Solver Support for Big Data Exploration and Mining

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Exploratory data analysis plays a key role in data-driven discovery in a wide range of domains including science, engineering and business. This project will enable data scientists from many domains to search and explore their large data sets far easier and faster than they do today. Rather than spending a lot time to set up exploration pipelines by combining multiple software tools, users will work with a single, general purpose and more usable system. Overall, this project will enable fundamentally richer means for data exploration and lead to significant productivity improvements; it will accelerate discovery and breakthroughs in many domains such as e-commerce, finance and science. This research will be incorporated in undergraduate and graduate coursework. The outreach activities include special research and education-focused programs that are geared towards undergraduates and high-school girls.

This research proposes to design and build a new prototype database system, called BigSolver, that will uniquely integrate constraint solving and data management techniques. The result will enable rich, highly-efficient means for generic ad hoc search, exploration and mining over large multidimensional data collections. BigSolver will allow Constraint Programming (CP) machinery to run efficiently inside a DBMS without the need to extract, transform and move the data. This marriage will offer the rich expressiveness and efficiency of constraint-based search and optimization provided by modern CP solvers with the ability of Database Management Systems (DBMSs) to store and query data at scale. This work will be an early yet transformative step in enriching the functionality of database systems towards new data- and search-intensive applications. The proposed effort will develop novel approaches for synopsis-based in-memory processing, speculative solving, search query optimization, parallel processing and load balancing, as well as architectural innovations, which will collectively yield performance and usability levels that far improve those of the state of the art.

For further information, see the project website at: http://database.cs.brown.edu/projects/SearchLight/

Institution.Name: Brown University
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: BROWN UNIVERSITY IN PROVIDENCE IN THE STATE OF RHODE ISLAND AND PROVIDENCE PLANTATIONS

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
Interactive exploration and mining over large data collections have become increasingly prevalent across many science, engineering and business domains. The key capability to support these activities is the efficient search and querying of large data sets.

The system that we developed as a prototype, called SearchLight, allows data scientists from many different domains to explore and mine their large datasets far easier and faster than they can do today. The developed approaches elevate constraint-based solving technology, a well-developed technology used for optimizing search operations, as a first-class functionality within data management systems. This work is the first to show how to use existing constraint-based solvers, without any major modifications, to operate on very large data sets. As a result, the tight integration of these two technologies, solvers and data management systems, significantly broadens the applicability and appeal of database systems for applications that demand sophisticated exploration and mining.

Rather than spending time setting up a complex software system, often using a combination of existing solvers libraries, databases and custom scripts, SearchLight offers a single and more usable system. Overall, SearchLight enables fundamentally richer means for data exploration and may lead to significant productivity improvements and profound impact on many areas such as science, e-commerce, and finance. Our prototype implementation and its comprehensive experimental evaluation point to impressive performance and productivity gains. As an additional outcome, we showed how to use modern learning techniques to compress data sets to much smaller sizes, so that they can fit in the main memory of computer systems during analysis. This significantly improves the speed of query processing and search.

Many students, graduate and undergraduate, who took part in this project gained substantial technical experience on an array of data technologies and software systems. This project already formed the basis of one completed PhD dissertation, one ongoing PhD dissertation, and multiple undergraduate senior projects. This project also led to the development of a course in predictive analytics, targeted towards graduate students and seniors, where students learn how to use data-driven techniques and optimization tools towards effective and informed decision making.

 


Last Modified: 01/14/2020
Modified by: Ugur Cetintemel

The key capability to support these activities is the efficient search and querying of large data sets. The system that we developed as a prototype, called SearchLight, allows data scientists from many different domains to explore and mine their large datasets far easier and faster than they can do today. As a result, the tight integration of these two technologies, solvers and data management systems, significantly broadens the applicability and appeal of database systems for applications that demand sophisticated exploration and mining. Rather than spending time setting up a complex software system, often using a combination of existing solvers libraries, databases and custom scripts, SearchLight offers a single and more usable system. Overall, SearchLight enables fundamentally richer means for data exploration and may lead to significant productivity improvements and profound impact on many areas such as science, e-commerce, and finance. Our prototype implementation and its comprehensive experimental evaluation point to impressive performance and productivity gains. As an additional outcome, we showed how to use modern learning techniques to compress data sets to much smaller sizes, so that they can fit in the main memory of computer systems during analysis. This significantly improves the speed of query processing and search.
